gemini.transcription:
To tru[lig:st] choſe tables that receaue thee more,
To keepe an adiun[lig:ct] to remember thee,
Were to import forgetfulne[lig:ff]e in mee.

123

NO time, thou [lig:s]halt not boa[lig:st] that I doe change,
Thy pyramids buylt vp with newer might
To me are nothing nouell,nothing [lig:s]trange,
They are but dre[lig:ff]ings of a former [lig:s]ight.
Our dates are bree[lig:s]e,and therefore we admire,
What thou do[lig:st] foy[lig:st] vpon vs that is ould,
And rather make them borne to our de[lig:s]ire,
Then thinke that we before haue heard them tould.
Thy regi[lig:s]ters and thee I both de[lig:s]ie,
Not wondring at the pre[lig:s]ent,nor the pa[lig:st],
For thy records,and what we [lig:s]ee doth lye,
Made more or les by thy continuall ha[lig:st]:
This I doe vow and this [lig:s]hall euer be,
I will be true di[lig:s]pight thy [lig:s]yeth and thee.

124

FMy deare loue were but the childe of [lig:st]ate,
It might for fortunes ba[lig:s]terd be vnfathered,
As [lig:s]ubje[lig:ct] to times loue,or to times hate,
Weeds among weeds,or [lig:fl]owers with [lig:fl]owers gathered.
No it was buylded far from accident,
It [lig:s]u[lig:ff]ers not in [lig:s]milinge pomp,nor falls
Vnder the blow of thralled di[lig:s]content,
Whereto th’inu[lig:s]iting time our fa[lig:s]hion calls:
It feares not policy that Heriticke,
Which workes on lea[lig:s]es of [lig:s]hort numbred howers,
But all alone [lig:s]tands hugely polliticke,
That it nor growes with heat,nor drownes with [lig:s]howres.
To this I witnes call the [lig:s]oles of time,
Which die for goodne[lig:ff]s,who haue liu'd for crime.

125

VVEr't ought to me I bore the canopy,
With my extern the outward honoring,
Of
Or layd great ba[lig:s]es for eternity,
Which proues more [lig:s]hort then wa[lig:st] orruining?
Haue I not [lig:s]eene dwellers on forme and fauor
Lo[lig:s]e all,and more by paying too much rent
For compound [lig:s]weets;Forgoinge [lig:s]imple fauor,
Pitti[lig:ff]ull thriuors in their gazing [lig:s]pent.
Noe, let me be ob[lig:s]equious in thy heart,
And take thou my oblacion,poore but free,
Which is not mixt with [lig:s]econds,knows no art,
But mutuall render.onely me for thee.
Hence,thou [lig:s]ubborn'd inform[lig:er], a trew [lig:s]oule
When mo[lig:st] impeacht,[lig:st]ands lea[lig:st] in thy controule.

126

THou my louely Boy who in thy power
Doe[lig:st] hould times fickle gla[lig:ff]e,his fickle,howers:
Who ha[lig:st] by wayning growne,and therein thou'rt,
Thy louers withering,as thy [lig:s]weet [lig:s]elfe grow'[lig:st].
She keepes thee to this purpo[lig:s]e,that her skill.
May time di[lig:s]grace,and wretched mynuit kill.
She may detaine,but not till keepe her tre[lig:s]ure!
Her Audite (though delayd)an[lig:s]wer'd mu[lig:st] be,
And her Quietus is to render thee.

( )
127

IN the ould age blacke was not counted faire,
Or if it weare it bore not beauties name:
But now is blacke beautie's [lig:s]ucce[lig:ff]iue heire,
And Beautie [lig:fl]anderd with a ba[lig:st]ard [lig:s]hame.
For [lig:s]ince each hand hath put on Natures power,
Faining the [lig:s]oule with Arts fau[lig:ff]e borrow'd face,
[lig:S]weet beauty hath no name no holy boure,
But is prophan'd,if not liues in di[lig:s]grace.

H3 Therefore
anomalies: Printer's mark 'H3' at the bottom right of the right column.
Parenthetical mark '( )' on the right column, above page number 127, indicating the end of Sonnet 126.
In Sonnet 123, line 4: The 'a' in 'shalt' appears slightly smudged or has a small ink spot.
In Sonnet 123, line 15: The word 'les' uses a short 's' at the end, which is uncommon for the period where 'ſſ' or 'ſs' was often used in variants of 'less'.
In Sonnet 126, line 14: The 'glaſſe' ligature 'ſſ' is printed very tightly, almost appearing as a single thick character.
In Sonnet 127, line 24: The 'ſucceſſiue' ligatures 'ſſ' are also printed very tightly.
In Sonnet 127, line 27: The 'fauſſe' ligature 'ſſ' is also printed very tightly.
gemini.notes: Long-s (ſ) has been preserved, and ligatures have been indicated with [lig:XX]. Ligatures were identified based on the visual appearance of combined characters commonly found in 17th-century typography (e.g., 'ſt' as a single glyph, 'ſſ' as a single glyph). The differentiation between 'ſ' and 'f' has been made carefully, especially at the beginning of words. Instances where 's' is a short 's' have been transcribed as such without 'lig:s' tag, for example, in 'pyramids' or 'records'. The 'fi' ligature was not found.
